data.title: Royal Oak Issues Recall For Flame Saber Lighters Due To Fire And Burn Risks
data.description:
WASHINGTON (dpa-AFX) - Royal Oak Enterprises LLC has issued a recall for approximately 190,560 units of their Royal Oak Flame Saber Lighters due to fire and burn hazards.

The lighters, which were sold nationwide at major retailers from November 2023 to October 2025, do not meet federal safety standards for child-resistant mechanisms and labeling requirements.

The recalled lighters are red in color with a black-and-gray checkered grip and feature hands-free operation and the 'Royal Oak' logo printed on the front. They were manufactured in China and sold for around $30 each.

The lighters pose a serious fire and burn risk, including potential risk of death, as they lack the required child-resistant mechanisms. Additionally, the lighters fail to meet labeling requirements under the Federal Hazardous Substances Act. No injuries have been reported so far related to the recalled products.

Consumers are advised to immediately stop using the lighters and contact Royal Oak for a full refund. Customers will receive instructions on how to safely destroy the lighter and submit proof of destruction to receive their refund.

Copyright(c) 2026 RTTNews.com. All Rights Reserved

Copyright RTT News/dpa-AFX

data.title: MP Materials swings to Q4 profit on US government price support
data.description:
Rare earths company MP Materials swung to a fourth-quarter profit, it said Thursday, exceeding analysts' expectations, driven by its price support agreement with the U.S. government and sale of magnetic material.

Rare earths are a group of 17 metals used to make magnets that turn power into motion. That industry is dominated by China, and the U.S. deal with MP Materials in 2025 was designed to loosen that nation's grip on the materials used to build weapons, electric vehicles and many electronics.

MP Materials controls the only rare earths mine in North America and processes those critical minerals in California. The company has also built a magnet facility in Texas.

For the quarter ended December 31, MP Materials posted net income of $9.4 million, or 5 cents per share, compared to a net loss of $22.3 million, or 14 cents per share, in the year-ago period.

Last year, the U.S. government guaranteed MP Materials a price floor of $110 per kilogram for its rare earths; those prices have roughly doubled over the past seven months, above that floor.

The company's results were aided by $51 million in price protection agreement income from the U.S. government.

Excluding stock-based compensation expenses and one-time items, the company earned 9 cents per share. By that measure, analysts expected results to break even, according to IBES data from LSEG.

Shares fell 2.9% to $58.25 in after-hours trading.

MP stopped shipping rare earths to China for processing last year, halting a major source of revenue, and it has been boosting processing in California.

MP Materials has been bringing its Texas magnet facility online in the past year. During the quarter, the company posted $19.9 million in magnetics revenue and $8.4 million in adjusted magnetics profit.

The company also said on Thursday it would build a second magnet facility as part of its agreement with the U.S. Department of Defense to manufacture 10,000 metric tons of magnets annually.

data.title: RBA Hike In March Is Being Underpriced — Market Talk
data.description: Money markets are underpricing the risk that the Reserve Bank of Australia will raise interest rates at its next policy meeting in mid-March. Stephen Walters, chief economist at Optimal Economics says pricing for March is around 20%. "That seems too thin," he adds. Inflation remains above target and the forces driving it higher are numerous, he adds. Against this backdrop it's encouraging to see some emerging recognition in Canberra that a 40-year high in government spending as a percentage of GDP is not warranted when the economy is running at fully capacity, he says(james.glynn@wsj.com; @JamesGlynnWSJ)

data.title: CORUS ENTERTAINMENT ANNOUNCES VOTING RESULTS FROM ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING OF SHAREHOLDERS
data.description:
TORONTO, Feb. 26, 2026 /CNW/ - Corus Entertainment Inc. announced today the voting results from its Annual General Meeting of Shareholders (the "Meeting") held virtually via online webcast on February 26, 2026.

A total of 3,268,160 Class A participating shares ("Class A Voting Shares"), representing 97.35% of the Company's 3,356,994 Class A Voting Shares that were issued and outstanding as at the January 16, 2026 record date of the Meeting, were voted in connection with the Meeting. Each of the matters put forth at the Meeting, being the election of directors, the appointment of auditors and authorization of the Board of Directors to fix the remuneration of such auditors, and the approval of a resolution to ratify and approve unallocated entitlements under the Company's stock option plan for the ensuing three years, was approved by a large majority of the voting shareholders as detailed in the Company's filing on www.sedarplus.ca.

Each of the seven director nominees set out in the Company's Management Information Circular dated January 28, 2026, was elected to hold office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until their successors are elected or appointed. The detailed results of the vote for the election of each director at the Meeting are set out below:

 
Director Nominees      Voted For  % For    Votes Against  Votes Against 
Fernand Bélisle   3,257,828  99.68 %         10,332         0.32 % 
Charmaine Crooks       3,257,828  99.68 %         10,332         0.32 % 
Mark Hollinger         3,257,828  99.68 %         10,332         0.32 % 
Barry L. James         3,257,828  99.68 %         10,332         0.32 % 
Margaret O'Brien       3,257,828  99.68 %         10,332         0.32 % 
Heather A. Shaw        3,257,828  99.68 %         10,332         0.32 % 
Julie M. Shaw          3,257,828  99.68 %         10,332         0.32 %

About Corus Entertainment Inc.

Corus Entertainment Inc. is a leading media and content company that develops, delivers and distributes high quality brands and content across platforms for audiences around the world. Engaging audiences since 1999, the company's portfolio of multimedia offerings encompass 25 specialty television services, 36 radio stations, 15 conventional television stations, digital and streaming platforms, and social digital agency and media services. Corus' roster of premium brands includes Global Television, W Network, Flavour Network, Home Network, The HISTORY(R) Channel, Showcase, Slice, Adult Swim, National Geographic and Global News, along with streaming platforms STACKTV, TELETOON+, the Global TV App and Curiouscast. For more information visit www.corusent.com.

SOURCE Corus Entertainment Inc (IR Group)

/CONTACT:

Copyright CNW Group 2026

data.title: Grindr 4Q Sales Rise as Paying User Base Grows
data.description:
By Kelly Cloonan

Grindr logged higher sales in its latest quarter as it continued to attract more paying users.

The dating-app company on Thursday posted a profit of $20.3 million, compared with a loss of $123.9 million a year earlier. The loss in the prior-year quarter was primarily driven by a $139 million non-cash loss from the change in fair value of Grindr's warrant liability, the company said.

Revenue climbed 29% to $126 million, compared with analyst estimates of $122 million.

Direct revenue, which makes up the bulk of the company's topline, rose 29% to $103 million. Advertising revenue grew due to continued demand from third-party advertising partners and strength internationally, the company said.

In 2025, paying users increased 17% to 1.3 million, with average direct revenue per paying user up 8% to $24.25.

For the full year, the company forecasts revenue of more than $528 million. Analysts project $528.9 million.

Grindr's board approved an extension of its buyback program to March 2029 and increased the share repurchase authorization to up to $450 million.

Write to Kelly Cloonan at kelly.cloonan@wsj.com

data.title: NUSCALE POWER Corp SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
NuScale Power Corp, a leader in the development of Small Modular Reactor (SMR) technology, has released its annual 10-K report, providing a comprehensive overview of its financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces. The report underscores NuScale's commitment to redefining nuclear power through its innovative NuScale Power Module™ (NPM) technology, which emphasizes safety, scalability, and cost-effectiveness.

Financial Highlights

  • Revenue: $31.5 million. The decrease in revenue was primarily due to a reduction in revenue recognized from the RoPower technology license agreement executed in 2024.
  • Gross Margin: $11.4 million. The increase in cost of sales compared to the prior year was due to the engineering services required by Fluor under their FEED Phase 2 contract with RoPower.
  • Loss from Operations: $(689.6) million. The increase in loss from operations was primarily due to the recognition of Milestone Contribution 1 of $507.4 million and higher strategic business development costs.
  • Net Loss: $(664.5) million. The net loss increased due to the trigger of Milestone Contribution 1 under the PMA and additional payments toward the acquisition and construction of long-lead material.
  • Net Cash Used in Operating Activities: $(459.6) million. Cash used in operations increased due to the trigger of Milestone Contribution 1 and payments associated with the tri-Party Agreement with the U.S. Department of Energy.

Business Highlights

  • Business Overview: NuScale is redefining nuclear power with its proprietary Small Modular Reactor (SMR) technology, the NuScale Power Module™ (NPM), which generates 77 MWe. The technology focuses on safety, scalability, and cost-effectiveness, leveraging passive safety features and a simplified design.
  • Regulatory Milestones: In May 2025, NuScale received approval from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) for its 6-unit 77 MWe NPM design, allowing U.S. customers to expedite construction and operating licensing.
  • International Market Development: NuScale has partnered with RoPower Nuclear S.A. in Romania to deploy a 6-unit 77 MWe NPM design at the Doicesti Power Station. The Romanian government approved the investment decision in February 2026, advancing the project to the next phase.
  • Strategic Partnerships: NuScale has contracted with ENTRA1 as its global strategic partner for the commercialization and development of power plants utilizing NPMs. ENTRA1 holds exclusive rights for worldwide commercialization, distribution, sales, and development of NuScale's products.
  • Geographical Performance: The demand for energy in foreign markets, particularly in Asia, is driven by population growth, industrialization, and urbanization. NuScale is focusing on these regions for long-term growth.
  • Domestic Market Focus: In the U.S., the demand for energy is driven by the growth of the data center industry and the government's objective to expand nuclear energy capacity to 400 gigawatts by 2050.
  • Technology and Safety Innovations: NuScale's NPM design incorporates proven light water reactor technology, natural circulation cooling, and a multi-module control room, enhancing safety and reducing operational costs.
  • Supply Chain and Manufacturing: NuScale has placed orders for long-lead items for the first twelve NPM upper reactor vessels and is progressing with manufacturing trials for key components, leveraging a global supply chain.
  • Future Outlook: NuScale aims to grow by replacing carbon-intensive coal-fired plants, expanding internationally, and developing new products like micro-reactors for niche markets. The company is also focused on advancing its technology platform and intellectual property portfolio.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Strategic Focus: NuScale is focused on commercializing its modular, scalable nuclear power technology, partnering with ENTRA1 for global commercialization and development. The company is advancing its strategic partnership with ENTRA1 to position its SMR technology in ENTRA1 Energy Plants, particularly targeting the Tennessee Valley Authority for up to 6 gigawatts of new nuclear power generation.
  • Capital Management: NuScale has been actively managing its capital through at-the-market (ATM) equity programs, raising significant funds to support its commercialization efforts. In 2025, the company issued and sold shares of Class A common stock for gross proceeds of $1,327.6 million through its Q4 2025 and Q3 2025 ATM Programs. The company has no debt and maintains a strong cash position with $836.4 million in cash and cash equivalents and $450.8 million in liquid investments as of December 31, 2025. NuScale has also entered into various purchase commitments to support the development of its NPMs.
  • Future Outlook: NuScale anticipates significant customer demand for its SMR technology outside the United States, driven by global trends in decarbonization and renewable energy demand. The company plans to continue its strategic partnership with ENTRA1 to expand its market presence and is focused on securing regulatory approvals to facilitate broader adoption of its technology. NuScale believes it has sufficient cash and access to capital markets to meet its cash requirements for the next 12 months and beyond, as it transitions from R&D to commercialization.

Challenges and Risks

  • Market and Operational Risks: NuScale faces unique challenges and risks as it redefines nuclear power with its SMR technology. The company has not yet entered into a binding contract to deliver its NPMs, which could delay deployment and impact financial performance. The market for SMRs is not yet established, and competition from other nuclear technologies and international players like China and Russia poses significant challenges. Additionally, the company relies heavily on strategic partnerships, which, if terminated, could hinder commercialization efforts.
  • Corporate Structure and Tax Risks: As a holding company, NuScale depends on distributions from NuScale LLC, and any financial deterioration of the subsidiary could impact liquidity. The company is also subject to complex tax arrangements, including a Tax Receivable Agreement that could result in substantial payments, potentially exceeding actual tax benefits.
  • Regulatory and Reputational Risks: Regulatory risks are significant, as the company must obtain approvals in each country it operates, and changes in U.S. trade policy could affect costs and supply chain dynamics. The public perception of nuclear energy and potential accidents pose reputational risks, while the constrained supply base could impact production schedules and costs.
  • Management's Discussion and Analysis: Management acknowledges the challenges of scaling production and securing contracts for NPMs. The company is focused on refining its design and manufacturing processes to enhance competitiveness. However, the need for additional funding to support operations and commercialization efforts is critical, and the company may face difficulties in securing financing on favorable terms. The potential loss of government incentives for nuclear power could also adversely affect market demand.
  • Market Risks: NuScale is exposed to market risks, including fluctuations in electricity prices and changes in regulatory environments. The company’s ability to compete in markets with low power prices is uncertain, and inflation could increase the cost of NPMs, affecting competitiveness. Additionally, cybersecurity risks are a concern, as breaches could impact operations and reputation. The company is also subject to risks from potential litigation, which could divert resources and impact financial performance.

SEC Filing: NUSCALE POWER Corp [ SMR ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: H2O AMERICA SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
H2O America, a leading water utility company, has released its annual Form 10-K report, detailing significant financial growth, strategic initiatives, and operational challenges. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's performance in 2025, highlighting key financial metrics, business operations, strategic plans, and the risks it faces in the evolving regulatory and market environment.

Financial Highlights

Operating Revenue: $800.59 million, reflecting a 7% increase from 2024 primarily due to rate increases in California and Connecticut.

Operating Income: $177.53 million, up from $170.50 million in 2024, driven by higher revenue despite increased administrative and general expenses.

Net Income: $102.58 million, representing a 9% increase from 2024, primarily driven by higher revenue associated with rate increases.

Diluted EPS: $2.92, compared to $2.87 in 2024, reflecting improved profitability and operational efficiency.

Business Highlights

Revenue Segments: Water Utility Services generated revenue from residential and business customers, industrial customers, public authorities, and other segments. The residential and business segment was the largest contributor, followed by public authorities and industrial customers.

Geographical Performance: H2O America operates in California, Connecticut, Texas, and Maine. Each region has distinct regulatory environments and operational challenges. California's operations are subject to CPUC regulations, Connecticut's to PURA, Texas's to PUCT, and Maine's to MPUC.

Sales Units: SJWC provides water services to approximately 232,000 connections, serving about one million people. CTWS serves approximately 143,000 connections, and TWC serves around 30,000 connections.

Future Outlook: H2O America plans to invest approximately $458 million in 2026 for capital improvements, excluding the Quadvest acquisition. The company also anticipates significant capital expenditures for PFAS treatment compliance by 2029.

Operational Challenges: The company faces challenges related to regulatory compliance, environmental standards, and water supply management, particularly in California due to long-term water supply issues.

Customer Growth: The company is focused on organic growth within its service areas and acquiring regulated water systems near its existing territories. The anticipated acquisition of Quadvest is expected to enhance operational scale and development pipeline.

Regulatory Environment: Each state has specific regulatory mechanisms, such as WICA in Connecticut and SIC in Texas, to address infrastructure investment and regulatory lag. These mechanisms help mitigate financial risks associated with regulatory changes.

Strategic Initiatives

Strategic Growth: H2O America is pursuing strategic growth through acquisitions, exemplified by the planned acquisition of Quadvest, L.P. and Quadvest Wholesale LLC, which is expected to enhance operational scale and development pipeline in the Houston, TX region. The company is also focusing on expanding its regulated customer base by acquiring water systems adjacent to existing territories.

Capital Management: In 2025, H2O America raised $185.2 million through long-term debt issuances and $122.8 million from equity offerings. The company also paid $58.6 million in dividends, representing 57% of net income, and has a history of increasing annual dividends for 58 consecutive years. The company maintains unsecured bank lines of credit totaling $370 million and has been actively managing its debt portfolio with new issuances and repayments to support capital expenditures and working capital needs.

Future Outlook: H2O America plans to invest approximately $458 million in capital expenditures in 2026, excluding acquisitions, with a focus on distribution system investments and compliance with environmental regulations. Over the next five years, the company expects to incur $2.568 billion in capital expenditures, including $400 million for PFAS treatment. The company aims to maintain access to external funding sources to support its capital investment programs and strategic growth initiatives.

Challenges and Risks

Operational and Integration Risks: H2O America, formerly SJW Group, is undergoing significant changes, including the acquisition of Quadvest, which introduces new operational and integration risks. The company is expanding its operations in Texas, which will increase its exposure to regulatory and market risks in that region.

Regulatory Risks: The proposed acquisition of Quadvest presents several risks, including regulatory approval delays, integration challenges, and potential failure to realize anticipated benefits. The company faces significant regulatory risks, particularly in obtaining necessary approvals from the Public Utility Commission of Texas (PUCT) and other regulatory bodies. Additionally, the integration of Quadvest's business may be complex and time-consuming, potentially impacting customer relationships and operational efficiency.

Litigation Risks: H2O America is also exposed to litigation risks, particularly concerning water quality and contamination. A class action lawsuit against a subsidiary, CWC, highlights the potential for significant legal costs and reputational damage. The company’s operations are subject to stringent environmental regulations, which could increase compliance costs and impact financial performance.

Water Supply Adequacy: The company faces operational risks related to water supply adequacy, which depends on factors such as rainfall, reservoir levels, and regulatory restrictions. Water shortages could lead to increased costs and operational challenges. The concentration of business in California, Texas, and Connecticut makes H2O America susceptible to regional risks, including political, regulatory, and environmental challenges.

Market Risks: H2O America is exposed to market risks, including interest rate fluctuations that could impact the cost of capital. The company’s substantial indebtedness, particularly related to the Quadvest acquisition, may reduce financial flexibility and increase borrowing costs. Additionally, the company faces risks related to inflation, which could increase operational costs and impact profitability if not offset by rate increases.

SEC Filing: H2O AMERICA [ HTO ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc., a specialty finance company focused on lending to middle-market companies, has released its 2025 10-K report. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in the current market environment.

Financial Highlights

Total Investment Income: $365.57 million, a decrease from $434.37 million in 2024, primarily due to a decline in base interest rates and tightening of credit spreads.

Net Investment Income After Taxes: $181.57 million, down from $252.55 million in 2024, reflecting lower total investment income.

Net Realized and Unrealized Gains (Losses): $(62.22) million, an improvement from $(189.50) million in 2024, driven by restructuring and exits of certain investments.

Net Increase (Decrease) in Net Assets from Operations: $119.27 million, up from $62.87 million in 2024, due to improved net realized and unrealized gains.

Basic and Diluted Net Investment Income Per Share: $1.57, a decrease from $2.20 in 2024, reflecting lower net investment income.

Business Highlights

Business Model: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. operates as a specialty finance company focused on lending to middle-market companies, primarily through direct originations of secured debt and select equity investments.

Investment Strategy: The company emphasizes leading the negotiation and structuring of loans or securities and holding investments to maturity, with a focus on investments that have maturities of three to ten years.

Portfolio Composition: As of December 31, 2025, the investment portfolio consisted of 564 investments in 171 portfolio companies across 40 industries, with a significant focus on software, healthcare providers & services, and healthcare technology.

Geographical Performance: The portfolio's geographic composition was primarily in the United States (94.8%), with additional investments in Canada (3.2%), the United Kingdom (1.5%), and India (0.5%).

Investment Yield: The weighted average yield on the total portfolio was 9.3% at amortized cost and 10.5% at fair value, indicating a strong return on investments.

Market Opportunity: The company identifies a large target market opportunity in the U.S. middle market, driven by a significant number of middle-market companies and a large amount of un-invested private equity capital.

Competitive Advantages: The company leverages Goldman Sachs' global platform, direct origination capabilities, and structuring expertise to source and manage investments effectively.

Future Outlook: The company plans to continue focusing on secured debt investments and may also invest in opportunistic investments to enhance risk-adjusted returns. It aims to provide consistent dividend distributions and attractive total returns to stockholders.

Strategic Initiatives

Strategic Debt Management: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. has focused on strategic debt management by repaying the 2025 Notes using proceeds from its Revolving Credit Facility and cash on hand. The company also issued $400 million of 2030 Notes and $400 million of 2029 Notes to align its debt maturity profile and interest rate exposure with its investment portfolio. Additionally, the company has entered into interest rate swaps to hedge against interest rate fluctuations, enhancing its financial stability.

Capital Management: The company has been actively managing its capital structure through a stock repurchase program, authorizing up to $75 million for repurchases if the stock trades below NAV. It also declared a quarterly base distribution and a supplemental distribution, reflecting its commitment to returning capital to shareholders. The company maintains a voluntary dividend reinvestment plan, allowing shareholders to reinvest dividends into additional shares. Furthermore, the company has utilized its Revolving Credit Facility to manage liquidity and support its investment activities.

Future Outlook: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. plans to continue leveraging its Revolving Credit Facility and explore additional credit facilities to capitalize on investment opportunities. The company aims to maintain a balanced approach to capital management, focusing on debt reduction and shareholder returns. It anticipates further strategic use of interest rate swaps to manage interest rate risk and align its liabilities with its predominantly floating rate investment portfolio.

Challenges and Risks

Market Risks: The company faces significant market risks due to potential disruptions and instability in capital markets, which could negatively impact debt and equity capital markets, affecting business operations. Political, social, and economic uncertainties, including conflicts and natural disasters, exacerbate these risks.

Regulatory Constraints: Regulatory constraints as a BDC limit operational flexibility and could lead to additional restrictions if BDC status is lost. The company must maintain RIC status to avoid corporate tax rates, which requires meeting specific distribution and diversification requirements.

Operational Risks: Cybersecurity incidents and reliance on information systems pose operational risks, potentially disrupting business and affecting financial conditions. The use of artificial intelligence introduces new risks, including data inaccuracies and increased competition, which could adversely impact operations.

Management Strategies: Management acknowledges the challenges posed by market volatility and economic conditions, which may limit investment opportunities and increase funding costs. The company plans to manage these risks by maintaining a diversified investment portfolio and leveraging its relationship with Goldman Sachs for strategic advantages. However, the competitive market for investment opportunities remains a significant challenge, with many competitors having greater resources and risk tolerance.

Interest Rate Risks: The company is exposed to interest rate fluctuations, which could impact the cost of debt and the ability to raise new capital. Inflation and changes in Federal Reserve policies may further affect borrowing costs and investment returns. The company employs interest rate swaps to mitigate some of these risks but acknowledges the inherent uncertainties in market conditions.

SEC Filing: Goldman Sachs BDC, Inc. [ GSBD ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026
